content: It's not as easy as it sounds. I'm tackling this for my app using a RAG based semantic search + direct memory lookup tool and memory extraction after chat sessions end.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: Part of the problem is context aware memory. Claude can choke down 200k tokens in a prompt but beyond like 50k it starts to lose the thread. Every bit of memory you inject eats into that context so you start losing ground. You have to make sure the memory you inject is relevant to what's being discussed

content: It's a bit more complicated than that. After memory extraction you have to build semantic connections and map them out into vector space. Claude needs to know what a memory means and what it's associated with so it knows what to pull up next time.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: its all just a big function that spits out a vector. Thats what modern AI is
author: pakeke#0

content: If you just rely on text search you get weird interactions like "mother in law" won't map to "family" because that's not the same text but with semantic connections they will
author: ticktockbent#0

content: Well sherlock holmes said that he has a set amount of storage space in his brain too, and that's why he discards irrelevant stuff and complies things that aren't so relevant but still need to be stored, and then only keeps the things at the front of his mind that are useful for what he needs
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: Also. There actally ARE humans, who compile memory in their brains by date and time. Wild. They can remember literally everything they've ever experienced. All the time.
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: Yes but a human brain can store much more than can fit in a single context window
author: ticktockbent#0

content: on an unrelated note, it's honestly surprising that transformers work at all ü§£
author: pakeke#0

content: it really is. They're like math wizardry
author: ticktockbent#0

content: What's a context window? Like the chat? is that a context window?
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: like it's so unintuitive that something so simple can display such emergently intelligent properties
author: pakeke#0

content: what a time to be alive honestly
author: pakeke#0

content: An LLM can only process a certain number of tokens in a single call, that's the context window. For claude it's about 200k tokens. That's why long chats have to end or be compacted, because they ran over the context limit
author: ticktockbent#0

content: OH. Because I've heard that every time you send a new prompt, it literally just appends that to the rest of the convo, and resends the ENTIRE convo. Okay. So you're saying that that entire process, can only use a set number of tokens or compute points. okay
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: Yep that's how it works. The whole chat is fed back in every time with notations on who said what. Think of it like the LLM's attention span. Once the chat is bigger than that, it can't really follow the conversation. Even at maximum it gets a little iffy about paying attention.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: So how would we fix that.... well he doesn't need to resend the entire process. It could compile the chat into notes about the chat... AH. I see. But then you lose some details which is why the AIs are awesome about highlevel abstract philosophy and crap when it comes to details. They can remember everything I tell them about metaphysics but somehow forget my name.
author: aurora_smith_#0

content:
But the most important thing to realize; is that the ONLY input an LLM takes is the context window.

It literally takes a stream of tokens, and spits out the next token.
Then it forgets everything, re-reads everything, (including the new token that was just added), and then spits out the NEXT token.

Isn't that incredible?

Imagine if you were having a conversation, and every time you said a word, you forgot what you were saying lol. That's pretty much the experience of LLMs, yet they still form cohesive sentences.
author: pakeke#0

content: Wait. They remember everything I tell them about metaphysics... and they're doing that because they recognize patterns...

author: aurora_smith_#0

content: Well different companies fix it in different ways. Some compact the chat and feed in a shorter summary but you lose nuance. Some just discard older messages but you lose information. Some make the context window bigger but then you add cost. Gemini can take 1 million tokens in context but might take longer to process.

content:
eg,
if model is writing a function, and it comes across a part that'll be complicated, it can write some "planning" comments for a while, like

/* [THINKING]
...
...
*/
and then continue code.
Postprocess script clears the CoT comment block
author: pakeke#0

content: Oh another thing I do which seems to work alright is I use a hierarchy in my claude.md - The claude.md is just a map to the codebase and I put agent files in other folders. The initial file just points to those files "If you're working on the frontend, look at /web/agents.md" etc and those have specifics for the code there. It helps it remain focused in a large code base

content:
Hi there, I've been struggling consistently with this issue for months where every character I type a line of claude code output disappears meaning you can't look at the previous output while typing a new response:https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/10239. It seemed to get fixed and then there was a regression not sure when though. Am currently on v2.1.2. There seems to have been many related duplicate issues open and closed.

My workaround previously was pinning to the version where this was originally fixed but now having issues with that version incorrectly thinking my opus token limit is used up üòï 

I'm posting here in case any has found a way to fix this for themselves? I love claude code and use it every day on max plan but this is making it so hard to use . If anyone has found a solution or if there is a fix in progress please let me know, would be much appreciated. Cheers üôè

content:
I love how AI understand the worst input.
> The user reported that the board is 'less flipped' but still incorrect. I analyzed the issue and realized that while I fixed the spatial rotation, I failed to invert the piece values. Consequently, Player 2's pieces were being rendered with Player 1's color during their turn. I am now updating 
> trainer.py
>  to invert the board values (board = -board) when it is Player 2's turn, ensuring correct color assignment.

> I've fixed the "identity crisis" in the visualization!
> 
> You were right‚Äîwhile my previous change fixed the orientation (so pieces didn't physically fly across the screen), it didn't fix the colors. Because the neural network always views the "current player" as Player 1 (Red), Player 2 was turning Red during their turn.

content:
For instance, literally had a whole custom harness around context management & optimization, and memory retrieval on a forked OpenCode that would do what neither could. 

LOTS of custom workflows and setups that make life unmeasurably easier compared to the core Claude Code experience. 

When they first rugged the 20X Max plan it made sense since you gotta cap these things somehow. 

But killing an entire part of your ecosystem, including all the "ambassadors" who'd promote Claude simply because of this its portability to apps like OpenCode throughout the dev community, is peak hypocrisy and frankly I think every harness that trusted Anthropic's Claude Code oAUTH should remove API support for Claude entirely.

This is a two-way street with the community you're building. Maybe throw the community a bone every once in a while if you wanna keep it, especially if the community still pays your Max plan & drives higher ongoing demand.

content: <@1279450111683989618> I think you're missing the bigger point. Which is better is a matter of opinion. There are known bugs i Claude Code tho, like /compact not working. But the big issue is that a lot of people don't want to be locked into a vendor tool that they can't see the source code, can't participate in bug fixes, can't fork and customize. And here's the thing - they're making money off the models either way!!! It's just ego and greed, like I said, because it helps them with vendor lock-in since it's a trust issue. But it's also wrong, and it's gonna work in the long term about as great as Yahoo's search engine worked.

content: Nah it just takes the first discord message link to share the embed so you don't have to click the link to see the message. It doesnt work if you link multiple messages though, it only grabs the first one, which is likely intended as mods are not a fan of large embeds and such.
